subSections.title: Readings
Etymology 1
Noun
Synonyms
subSections.text:
* {{sense|thorn}} {{ja-r|刺|とげ|rom=-}}, {{ja-r|棘|とげ}}; {{ja-r|針|はり|rom=-}}, {{ja-r|鍼|はり}}
* {{sense|downmarket prostitute}} {{ja-r|端%女%郎|はし%じょ%ろう}}

subSections.title: Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|うばら}}

From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=うばら|-}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>  Used in the ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'', completed some time after 759 CE.<ref>{{RQ:Manyoshu|16|3832}}, text [http://jti.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man16Yo.html#3832 here]</ref>

Appears alongside the ''umara'' form (see below), suggesting possible {{w|Prenasalized consonant|prenasalization}}, perhaps realized as *{{IPAchar|/umbara/}}.

[[supersede|Superseded]] by ''ibara'' above.

subSections.title: Noun
Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|うまら}}

From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=うまら|-}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>  Used in the ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'', completed some time after 759 CE.<ref>{{RQ:Manyoshu|20|4352}}, text [http://jti.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man20Yo.html#4352 here]</ref>

Appears alongside the ''ubara'' form (see above), suggesting possible {{w|Prenasalized consonant|prenasalization}}, perhaps realized as *{{IPAchar|/umbara/}}.

[[supersede|Superseded]] by ''ibara'' above.

subSections.title: Noun
Etymology 4
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|むばら}}

Appears in the {{w|Heian period}},<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> apparently as a shift from ''ubara''.  Used in ''{{w|The Tales of Ise}}'' dating to the early 900s CE.<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

Considering the earlier free alternation between ''ubara'' and ''umara'', suggesting a possible {{w|Prenasalized consonant|prenasalized}} pronunciation such as *{{IPAchar|/umbara/}}, this ''mubara'' may have arisen from an alternative spelling to clarify nasalization.  Old Japanese [[orthography]] had no unambiguous means of specifying the nasal [[coda]] [[consonant]] {{ja-r|ん}}, using {{ja-r|む}} instead.  In fact, the modern kana {{ja-r|ん}} developed from a [[hentaigana]] form of {{ja-r|む}}.

[[supersede|Superseded]] by ''ibara'' above.
